This document has been prepared for use as a guideline to safety during the operation of the facility.  These guidelines are based on applicable government regulations, insurance related safety and risk management requirements, and accepted safety practices within the ethanol industry













Forward

Calgren Renewable Fuels, LLC (Pixley) has a new dry mill ethanol production facility located at 11704 Road 120 / PO Box E, in Pixley, Cali

fornia, operating under the name of Calgren Renewable Fuels. This ?written document? has been assembled to facilitate Calgren Renewable Fuels in fulfilling the Occupational Safety and Health Administration?s (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) and the Environmental Protection Agency?s (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements.  These two programs are intended to prevent releases and minimize the consequence of releases of certain hazardous chemicals.



The PSM and RMP requirements are similar, but there is one notable difference.  PSM places an emphasis on employee safety, while RMP emphasizes protecting the surrounding community and environment.  Due to Facility?s chemicals and processes, the PSM and RMP standards require the following elements be addressed for the covered processes:



* Employee participation

* Process safety information

* Process hazard analysis

* Standard operating procedures

* Training

* Contractors

* Pre-startup safety review

* Mechanical integrity

* Hot work permit

* Management of change

* Incident investigation

* Emergency planning and response

* Compliance audits

* Trade secrets





The first portion of this manual, is structured to address and meet the requirements of the PSM standard with respect to the flammable (denaturant/alcohol) and anhydrous ammonia at the Facility.  The second portion of this manual, is structured to address the RMP standard requirements, which apply to those same chemicals at the Facility.  In this manual, both of these programs are discussed together wherever applicable.  Appendices A through U are attached and contain supporting documentation, including: process safety information, checklists and forms necessary to fulfill the requirements of both the PSM and RMP standards.



Process Safety Management



Employee Participation



A team of individuals, with expertise in production, operations, process, engineering, maintenance and safety was established during October of 2007.  Calgren

Renewable Fuels identified current employees who will operate and maintain the ammonia system to participate in the development and implementation of the PSM written plan.



The team compiled the Process Safety Information (PSI) and conducted PHAs on the ammonia system in October 2007.



The team was trained to perform the hazard analysis methodology, the ?What If? assessment and portions of the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) methodology in order to conduct the PHA(s) on the required process system at the Facility.



Process operations had the opportunity to comment on the PSM elements and the PHA process.  Because the facility had not started its operations in October of 2007, the pertinent PSM information will be shared with affected personnel during their initial job startup, at safety meetings, and other forms of employee training sessions.



The Production Manager, designated by the General Manager, will assemble the PHA team every three years at a minimum to review operating procedures, conduct audits and the PHA.



The following individuals are currently assigned to the PHA team:



* Production Manager

* EH&S Manager

* Lab Manager 

* Lead Operator

* Operator

No task is so urgent or important that it cannot be done safely.

Our Goal, each and every day, is to leave as we arrived at the start of our day.



Calgren Renewable Fuels employees must make every effort to keep accidents at an absolute minimum. This can be done only by employees and management?s dedication to the prevention of accidents. It is intended that the above two slogans be our basis for assuring an efficient, safe and healthful work place for our employees. 



Our philosophy, that the prevention of accidents and efficiency in operation are inseparable, and will guide our plans and actions. The prevention of accidents requires the cooperation and support of all employees. We earnestly solicit and expect this support for the protectio

n and welfare of each and every employee.



Calgren Renewable Fuel?s management team is responsible to see that the safety program is implemented as prescribed, and that all employees follow the safety policies and procedures as outlined. Calgren Renewable Fuel?s management team is not only a morally and legally responsibility to have a safe working environment, but also, has an economic responsibility.  Nothing is more important to our company?s success than a safe, efficient, and healthy working environment.

Ammonia and Its Properties (Appendix A - Ammonia MSDS)



Ammonia is a colorless liquid with a strong, intense, suffocating odor.  It is a common molecule, given off by living organisms.  It is used to make fertilizers, animal food, synthetic fibers, glues and explosives.  It is also used in the treatment and refining of metal, and the manufacture of nitric acid, hydrazine hydrate and acrylonitrile.  It is often used in refrigeration. 



?Total ammonia? refers to the sum of ammonia (NH3) plus the ionized form (NH4+).  The toxicity of liquid ammonia solutions is primarily due to the presence of NH3, the percentage of which increases with pH and temperature.  Therefore, the toxicity of ?total ammonia? is greater in more alkaline water at higher temperatures.  It is also more toxic under conditions of decreased oxygen concentrations.  



Ammonia is a severe irritant of the eyes, respiratory tract and skin.  Exposures to and inhalation of large concentrations of aqueous ammonia can cause severe corneal irritation, dypsnea, bronchiospasm, chest pain and pulmonary edema, which may be fatal.  Exposure of the eyes to liquid ammonia may cause serious injury to the cornea and deeper structures and sometimes loss of sight.  Skin contact can cause extreme first- and second-degree burns and, if extensive, may be fatal. Extremely high concentrations of vapor can also result in skin burns.  With skin and mucous membrane contact, burns are of three types:  cryogenic (from liquid), thermal (from exothermic dissociation of ammonium hydroxide) and chemical (alkaline).



Personnel should avoid direct contact with ammonia.  If a less toxic chemical cannot be substituted for a h

azardous substance, engineering controls are the most effective way to reduce exposures.   The best protection is to enclose the operation and/or provide local exhaust ventilation at the site of the chemical release.  Using respiratory protection is less effective than engineering controls, but is still advisable whenever working with or around ammonia.  A NIOSH-approved, full-face piece respirator with ammonia vapor cartridge or canister is sufficient at low exposures.  A self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) with full-face piece and pressure demand is the recommended respiratory protection.



Administrative controls should also be in place to minimize the potential for human exposures.  These may include written procedures or policies, which specify the methods and techniques that will be practiced whenever personnel work with ammonia.



Acute ecological effects may include the death of animals, birds, or fish and death or low growth rate in plants.  Acute effects are seen two to four days after animals or plants are exposed.  Under natural conditions of pH and temperature, ammonia has a moderate acute toxicity to aquatic life.  No data is available on the short-term effects of ammonia on plants, birds or land animals. Chronic (long-term) toxic effects may include shortened life span, reproductive problems, lower fertility and changes in appearance or behavior in exposed animals.  These effects can be seen long after the first exposure. Ammonia is not expected to accumulate in the tissues of fish.



Ammonia is highly soluble in water.  Concentrations of 1,000 milligrams and more will mix with a liter of water.  Total ammonia is non-persistent in water, with a half-life of less than two days.  The half-life of a pollutant is the amount of time it takes for one-half of the chemical to be degraded.  



Proper training of all transporters will reduce the likelihood of an accident resulting in a leak or release to the environment.  The correct use of DOT labeli

ng on containers, trucks and rail cars will enable emergency responders to react properly and quickly to any disaster thereby reducing the potential risk to the environment and to personnel.



Ammonia should be segregated during storage from incompatible chemicals to minimize the risk of cross-contamination.  Storage buildings should be equipped with appropriate fire protection systems (alarms, sprinklers, emergency lighting and portable fire extinguishers).



US, federal regulations require that a release of 100 lb. or more of ammonia must be reported immediately to the National Response Center at (800) 424-8802, the SERC and the LEPC. In California, ALL releases must be reported to CUPA, state and local agencies. Additional state and local regulations may apply. SUGGESTED LOCAL ACTION: Stop leak if feasible. Avoid breathing ammonia. Evacuate personnel not equipped with protective clothing and equipment. Use copious amounts of water spray or fog to absorb ammonia vapor. DO NOT put water on liquid ammonia. Contain run-off to prevent ammonia from entering a stream, lake, sewer, or ditch. Any release of this material, during the course of loading, transporting, unloading or temporary storage, must be reported to U.S. DOT as required by 49 CFR 171.15 and 171.16.

ammonia system will prevent such releases or result in a controlled release within the process.  Employees will be trained to identify deviations from these operating limits and how to take corrective action when required.





Training



Calgren Renewable Fuels is committed to establishing the safest possible work environment for its employees and has established a comprehensive training program to meet the requirements under the PSM OSHA standard.



Producers, packagers and distributors of ammonia cannot provide safety training for their customers every time a new employee is hired or new plant assignments are made.  Therefore, the burden to properly train these people is on the end-user.  To a great extent, safety in handling ammonia depends on the effectiveness of employee training, proper safety instructions and the use of suitable equipment.  It is the responsibility of the employer to train employees and to document such training as appropriate and as required by regulation.



Calgren Renewable Fuels has established initial and refresher training modules for several of their safety programs.  Operators, maintenance, instrumentation and lab personnel are provided training on an annual basis.  The EH&S Manager will coordinate and document the safety training that is provided.



Contractors are not typically used at the Facility. However, when contractors are used, they will be provided training based on the work they conduct on ammonia system.  Their employers are responsible for providing OSHA-mandated training.  XXXXXXXXXX will provide the appropriate training to contractors required by the PSM standard.  Training is documented and maintained by EH&S Manager.

20.  The minimum HAZWOPER training varies, depending on the level of the response.

Pre-Startup Safety Review



Calgren Renewable Fuels will conduct a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) prior to a new process starts up or when changes are made to the existing ammonia system.  The Plant Manager and the Production Manager will determine if a process ?change? qualifies, under the MOC, or whether it?s a ?replacement in kind?.  Modifications to the process will require a pre-startup review.



Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures



The Production Manager will initiate the pre-startup review.  The Production Manager (PSM coordinator) will assemble a pre-startup review team.  This team will be responsible for conducting the pre-startup review.  The pre-startup review team will complete the system pre-startup checklist and the system pre-startup safety review completion form.



The Calgren Renewable Fuels will not start the ammonia system until all startup procedures are completed.  The pre-startup team will ensure that items identified by the review team will be corrected before the chemical is introduced into the system.



Overview

When a modification is planned to the process/system, the General Manager and Production Manager will determine if the change qualifies as ?modified? (significant change) or ?replacements in kind? under the MOC guidelines.  If the change qualifies as modified, then the following process will occur:



Process

All steps must be completed prior to placing a chemical or piece of equipment back into the process or system.

1. The Production Manager and maintenance / mechanical manager will meet with the PSSR team and specifically list items that need to be updated.  He or she will review the modification so that: construction

and equipment meet design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place, updated and adequate; operator training has been complete; and management of change program requirements is met.  

2. The PSSR team will fill out ?System Pre-Startup Checklist? checking off items as they are complete.

3. Resolve issues from checklist (2).

4. PSSR team completes and signs the ?System Pre-Startup Safety Review Completion? form authorizing startup of the modified system.

5. Proceed with system startup.

Emergency Planning and Response



Calgren Renewable Fuels is prepared to respond to emergencies by using local community responders to mitigate any significant chemical release.  The emergency response team?s actions and employee evacuation will aid in the prevention of a catastrophic event from occurring.



Calgren Renewable Fuels employees will only respond to incidental spills/releases within the immediate spill or release area (if it?s safe to do so).  If the incident escalates, Calgren Renewable Fuels employees will evacuate and initiate the 911 emergency system simultaneously.



Response procedures will involve isolating the area and evacuating all nonessential employees.  A hazard assessment is conducted to determine the resources needed.  The ammonia release will be controlled, contained or confined by the local or regional HAZMAT teams to prevent further damage or injury.  Further details of response procedures can be found in Emergency Response Plan (Appendix G).  



The General Manager or Production Manager will document all ammonia spill or releases and ?near-misses? by completing the incident report form  This form will document the specific events of the release.  The responding team will critique the emergency response upon completing all response procedures.  The response team commander will facilitate the critique session.



Compliance Audits



The intent of the compliance audit is to determine the effectiveness of the PSM program and identify any deficiencies that could lead to injuries or illnesses related to releases of ammon

ia.  The audit team will provide management a report of the identified deficiencies and needed corrective actions.



Compliance Audit

Introduction



This document was developed for the Facility located at 11704 Road 120, Calgren Renewable Fuels, Pix

ley, CA 93256 in an effort to fulfill criteria of the RMP standard, as required by Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act and regulated by 40 CFR, Part 68.



Under the accidental release provisions of the Clean Air Act, regulated sources are required to conduct hazard assessments, review off-site consequence analyses and develop a risk management plan.  The hazard assessment discusses off-site consequences for a Worst Case Scenario (WCS) and Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) of the regulated substances(s) at this Facility.  From the subsequent analyses of the scenario(s), accident prevention programs will be reviewed, revised, and implemented.  Emergency response programs will also be reviewed/enhanced in an effort to minimize the impact of the potential consequences resulting from an accidental release of regulated substances in the covered process.



There are two primary purposes of the development of the Section 112(r) regulations, paraphrasing the intents of the U.S. Congress and EPA:



1. To encourage sources to reduce the probability and severity of accidental releases having the potential to cause harm to the public and the environment

2. To stimulate a dialogue between industry and the public to improve accident prevention and emergency response



The RMP standard applies to facilities that store greater than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process at any one time.  The facility has a process involving quantities toxics ammonia  above the threshold quantity (TQ) of 10,000 pounds, listed  in 40 CFR, Section 68.115. Therefore, EPA?s RMP applies.  Toxics (ammonia) are the only substances in the Facility?s current chemical usage inventory, which would be present in quantities above the TQ limits set by the EPA, triggering the requirement for submitting this RMP.



EPA has established three levels of performance within RMP development.  Program 1 is the least regulatory intensive, Program 3 is the most.  In the first step, facilities must

determine which of the three program levels apply for each ?covered process?.  Once the Facility makes this determination, there are four other steps (each step containing specific criteria depending on which program level applies to the process), which must be fulfilled to complete the other aspects of the RMP.  The other elements of the RMP are outlined as follows and thoroughly defined within this document:



Applicability  Determines if the Facility is subject to the RMP rule and what program level of compliance is applicable



Hazard Assessment (HA) ? Conducts an off-site consequence analysis with worst-case and alternative case release scenarios and includes a five-year accident history



Prevention Program (PP)  Identifies ways the Facility can prevent and detect accidental releases



Emergency Response Program (ERP)  Identifies methods the Facility uses to protect the public and the environment from accidental releases



Risk Management ?Plan?  Summarizes the Risk Management Program for submittal



The Facility is a conventional ethanol plant with a planned production of 55 million gallons/year of denatured ethanol.  The quantity of anyhdrous ammonia used at the Facility is greater than the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, which is EPA?s criteria for requiring the development and submittal of information found in this RMP.



Anhydrous ammonia is considered hazardous by EPA standards.  The same properties that make this chemical valuable for ethanol production also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling of this chemical to prevent unnecessary human exposure and to reduce the impact or threat to nearby members of the community.  Safety depends upon the manner in which the Facility handles the chemical, combined with safety devices inherent in the design of this Facility, and the training of our personnel.
